title: Leicester Mercury published Citizens Advice is kept busy with EU queries
text:
Citizens Advice is kept busy with EU queries By Leicester Mercury | Posted: July 13, 2016 By Staff reporter Citizens Advice LeicesterShire has received queries about Brexit Citizens Advice is kept busy with EU queries X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
Citizens Advice LeicesterShire is advising that the referendum vote to leave the EU does not mean any immediate changes to consumer rights, employment law or immigration rules. 
A new Citizens Advice webpage on the potential impact of Brexit has had tens of thousands of views. 
Advice has also reached 230,000 people on Facebook and 232,000 via Twitter. 
In the immediate wake of the "no" vote, immigration, citizenship and law changes were at the forefront of people's minds, the charity said. 
It said it was reasonable to expect the Government to legislate in light of leaving the EU, but it would be some time before that happens. Analysis of people seeking online help from Citizens Advice in the first 24 hours after the vote showed immigration was the top search term, with citizenship third. Brexit was the seventh most popular search. 
Read more: MPs will debate second EU referendum after 4 million sign petition 
Citizens Advice LeicesterShire has also received queries about how Brexit will affect immigration, citizenship and employment. 
Th charity is encouraging people to seek advice if they are unsure about their rights or feel they have experienced discrimination. 
Richard Evans, chief executive at Citizens Advice LeicesterShire said: "People have lots of questions about what leaving the EU means for their day-to-day lives. 
"For some people, it is as significant as what country they can call home. For others, it is about their rights at work or personal finances. 
"It is important to remember nothing changes yet and that for the time being all rights remain the same. 
"It is likely to be several years before any changes to the law come into effect. 
"We are here to help anyone who has a query about their rights and encourage people to come to us if they think they have been treated unfairly or discriminated against." 
Anyone requiring advice or support can get help online or on 0300 330 1025.
